yaml.title: Pixel Process
yaml.subtitle: Start Small | Iterate Often | Improve Always
yaml.description: Master the pieces to master the whole. From pixels to data points to lines of code, learn how to break down complexity, practice transferable skills, and build toward seeing the full picture.

markdown.markdown:
Welcome to PxP! Curious about how it all fits together? Start anywhere, follow your path, and discover how small pieces become powerful systems. ::: {.callout icon="none" .custom-callout .pxp-ref title="Project Navigation"} Quickly find all relevant content with a search term using the üîç in the top right of every page. This will search the contents of the entire project. A quick and easy tool if you are not sure where to look.\nThese icons indicate the type of content to: - {{< fa regular window-maximize >}} Web page - {{< fa regular rectangle-list >}} Jupyter Notebook - {{< fa regular file-code >}} Interactive Notebook (runs directly in your browser, no downloads needed) ::: This isn‚Äôt a course ‚Äî it‚Äôs a toolkit. Pixel Process is designed for exploration, not checklists. You won‚Äôt find step-by-step lessons or a strict progression. Instead, start by choosing a goal that excites you ‚Äî maybe you want to: - Automate a repetitive task with Python - Build a portfolio-worthy recommender system - Standardize your projects with consistent structure and tools From there, explore freely. Each section of the site offers building blocks: beginner to advanced, theory to implementation. You‚Äôll need to spot your own gaps, follow your curiosity, and piece together what matters most to your workflow. This path isn‚Äôt about completing a syllabus ‚Äî it‚Äôs about creating momentum. ## Jump into Hot Topics :::{.quick-links}
  • {{< fa regular window-maximize >}} About ‚Üí PxP mission, values, and team
  • {{< fa regular window-maximize >}} Jump In ‚Üí No downloads, no setup-jump into basic Python
  • {{< fa regular window-maximize >}} Machine Learning ‚Üí A guide to machine learning
  • {{< fa regular window-maximize >}} Random Forest (NB) ‚Üí Deep dive into decision trees and random forest models
  • {{< fa regular window-maximize >}} Perspective: Pixels & Pictures ‚Üí Context dependent perception
  • {{< fa regular window-maximize >}} Tools Overview ‚Üí Editors, linters, and formatters, oh my!
::: ## [Getting Started](/getting-started/index.qmd) Install tools, launch notebooks, and get productive in minutes.

Basic Overview

FAQs ‚Üí FAQs when getting started with programming
Troubleshooting Basics ‚Üí A guide to problem-solving and debugging
How to: Jupyter Notebooks ‚Üí Intro to using and navigating notebooks

Jump In

Jump In ‚Üí No downloads, no setup-jump into basic Python
Datatypes and Operators ‚Üí Jump into Python - Part 1
Variables and Functions ‚Üí Jump into Python - Part 2
Errors and Experimentation ‚Üí Jump into Python - Part 3

R Introduction

R Intro PDF ‚Üí PDF companion to the R intro notebook series
R: Basic Commands (NB) ‚Üí Get started with R
R: Datasets (NB) ‚Üí Vectors and datasets in R
R: Data Basics (NB) ‚Üí Create, edit, and summarize vectors in R
R: Import/Export (NB) ‚Üí Loading and saving data with R
R: Data Vizualization Basics (NB) ‚Üí Basic plotting functions in R
R: Data Analysis (NB) ‚Üí Begin analyzing with correlations, ttests, and more
## [Foundations](/foundations/index.qmd) Core Python, data loading/cleaning, and visualization basics.

Datasets

Dataset Exploration ‚Üí Guide to evaluating tabluar datasets
Dataset Exploration (NB) ‚Üí Verify data dimensions, datatypes, and quality

Data Visualization

Data Visualization Basics ‚Üí Learn about turning data into stories
Data Visualization Basics (NB) ‚Üí Start turning data into stories
Data Viz Building Blocks ‚Üí Core features behind data viz
Data Viz Building Blocks (NB) ‚Üí Code example for core features behind data viz

Image Analysis

## [Machine Learning](/machine-learning/index.qmd) Worked notebooks and concepts‚Äîfrom regression and classification to trees and evaluation.

Models & Metrics

What can ML do? ‚Üí Overview of data and algorithms for ML
Random Forest (NB) ‚Üí Deep dive into decision trees and random forest models

Classification

Iris Classification (NB) ‚Üí Complete classification pipeline based on Iris dataset

Regression

Housing Regression (NB) ‚Üí Complete regression pipeline based on housing dataset
## [Workflow](/workflow/index.qmd) Environments, linters, automation, and project structure for calm, repeatable work.

Tools

Tools Overview ‚Üí Editors, linters, and formatters, oh my!
Scripts and Notebooks ‚Üí When and why to use notebooks vs scripts

Customization

Command Line Interface ‚Üí Don't just learn CLI, optimize it
## [Perspectives](/perspectives/index.qmd) Reflections and insights into tech and trends

AND

Perspective: Pixels & Pictures ‚Üí Context dependent perception
::: {.callout icon="none" .custom-callout .d-bugz title="Start Your Journey"} From experience, I can attest learning everything is overwhelming, exhausting, and unnecessary. Focus on what you want to build or understand. Learn what you need as you go. And don‚Äôt be afraid to change course ‚Äî that‚Äôs part of the process, too. **Start small** ‚Äî expertise doesn‚Äôt happen in a day **Iterate often** ‚Äî progress comes through refactoring, revisiting, and rethinking **Improve always** ‚Äî focus on what matters now, and let your skills grow with your goals :::
Start where you are. Use what you have. Learn what you need
Each section of this project is a stepping stone. Start where it makes sense for you ‚Äî revisit what you need, skip what you don‚Äôt. The best path is the one that *fits* your needs.
